dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Now, I know what you’re thinking: “What the heck do I need a five- spindle for? I barely sell enough shakes to justify my single spindle.” Right? Wrong. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Paulsen, are you familiar with the notion of the chicken and the egg? I mention it because I believe it’s applicable here: Do you not need a Multimixer because you're not selling enough milk shakes? Or are you not selling enough milk shakes because you don’t have a Multimixer? I firmly believe it’s the latter. You see, your customers, they know that if they order a shake from your establishment, it’s going to be a terrific wait. They’ve ordered one before, and by golly they’re not gonna make that mistake again. But if you had, say, a Prince Castle- brand five-spindle Multimixer with patented direct-drive electric motor, you could greatly increase your ability to produce delicious, frosty milk shakes fast. And before long, mark my words, dollars to donuts, you'd be selling more of those suckers than you can shake a stick at. Increase supply, demand will follow. Chicken and the egg. You follow my logic? Of course you do. You’re a bright, forward- thinking fella who knows a good idea when he hears it. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whaddaya say? ON THE OWNER-- pondering thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Nah. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks anyway.  EXT. ED’S DRIVE-IN - PARKING LOT - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc lugs the heavy Mulitmixer back to his car. He lifts into the trunk, wincing from his bad back. INT. KROC’S CAR —- MOMENTS LATER Kroc sits in his car checking his APPOINTMENT BOOK. His n sales call: DEE DEE’S DRIVE-IN - 1 P.M. He checks his watch. It’s 12:05. He turns on the car, pul into a customer spot in front of Ed’s Drive-In. He looks at the MENU BOARD, taking in the vast, seemingly random assortment of items: BBQ beef sandwiches, hot tama peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, chili dogs, etc. INT. KROC’S CAR - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc sits in his car, waiting for his food. He looks at h watch. It’s 12:50. He lets out a heaving, exasperated sig KROC’S POV, the view out his windshield: a rowdy TEEN-HAN SCENE. Rock-and-roll blasting from cars; female CARHOPS o rollerskates dodging grabby male patrons; leather-jackete cigarette-smoking hoodlums smacking each other around. Kroc is the oldest customer by a mile--and seemingly the one with anywhere to be. He HONKS his horn, summoning his CARHOP. She comes skating over holding a tray of Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Miss, how much longer?

dialogues.speaker: CARHOP GIRL
dialogues.text: Should be any minute.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You said that 20 minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: CARHOP GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, we're real-- She JUMPS-SQUEALS, startled. The tray of Cokes goes flyin into the car, SPILLING ALL OVER KROC’S LAP. Several glass and plates fall on the ground, SHATTERING. Carhop Girl spins around, sees a GUY behind her cracking He just pinched her butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis! (re: Kroc, soaked) Look what you made me do!

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Sorry, gramps. Dennis scampers off toward his pack of laughing friends. carhop goes chasing after him, mad but not actually mad. ON KROC-- looking down at the pool of bubbly brown liquid his lap. He HONKS, leans out the window.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Could I get some napkins? No one hears him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON the pants drying on the shower’s curtain rod.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s going great. CUT TO: the NEXT ROOM. Kroc sitting on the bed, on the ph RAY KROC (CONT’D) Lot of good leads today. Real strong leads. Through the phone, a tiny passive-aggressive sigh. RAY KROC (CONT’D) (prickly) What?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing. That's wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: There’s tremendous interest.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sure there is.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course, Ray. Why wouldn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc sits on the edge of the bed, roiling from the call. takes off his shirt, undressing for bed. His bare torso b numerous surgery scars: heart, gall bladder, etc. He reaches over to the night stand, grabs a fifth of Cana Club. Unscrews the cap.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Kroc, in pajamas, stands before a PORTABLE PHONOGRAPH. He drops the needle on a record.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Kroc lies in bed in the darkened room, eyes closed. A soothing baritone fills the air--

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing in the world can take the place of persistence. Talent will not; nothing is more common than unsuccessful men with talent. Genius will not; unrewarded genius is almost a proverb. ANGLE ON record sleeve next to the phonograph: “THE POWER THE POSITIVE” BY DR. CLARENCE FLOYD NELSON

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Education will not; the world is full of educated derelicts. Persistence and determination alone are omnipotent. QUICK CUTS to other snippets of the record:

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I grabbed that brush, and I shined up those boots so bright, Pastor Walker could see his reflection in them! Later--

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The lesson there being, it’s not what you do but how you do it. Any job worth doing is worth doing well.  Later-- Later-- Later-- Later-- Later--

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I like to say, it’s not the size of the dog in the fight, it’s the size of the fight in the dog.

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Misfortune is just a stepping stone to fortune.

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I said to myself, “Clarence, you’ve got to muddle through this!”

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How a man handles adversity is the true measure of a man.

dialogues.speaker: RECORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Heck, anyone can paddle in a sunshower!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen of another drive-in, Kroc pitching to the OWN The scene is virtually identical to the previous day’s.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Increase supply, demand will follow. Chicken and the egg. You follow my logic? Of course you do. You're a bright, forward-thinking fella who knows a good idea when he hears it. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whaddaya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc lugs the sample Multimixer back to his car.  INT. KROC’S CAR - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc is pulled up to a customer spot in front of Joe’s Dr In. The scene before him is very much like the one at Ed’ Drive-In, a riot of teenage rowdiness. He looks at his watch. It’s 12:45. He HONKS, shouting out no one in particular:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Could someone tell me when my... He trails off as a female CARHOP approaches with a tray. hooks the tray onto his car door.

dialogues.speaker: CARHOP
dialogues.text: Enjoy. She heads off. He lifts the cover off his plate, primed t dig in. His face falls at the sight of the hamburger bene He leans out the window, honks.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I ordered the barbecued beef! He’s howling into the void. EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - LATER Another drive-in. Kroc with the OWNER.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Mr. Merriman, are you familiar with the notion of the chicken and the--

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: No, thank you. The Owner disappears into the restaurant. Kroc, shut down lugs the Multimixer over to his nearby car, heaves it int the trunk. He takes a swig from his FLASK. EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - MOMENTS LATER Kroc at a pay phone, dialing a long-distance number.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Prince Castle, how may I help you?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hi, June.  INT. PRINCE CASTLE SALES —- CONTINUOUS A modest office in a Chicago high-rise. At the reception is secretary JUNE MARTINO. (Intercut as necessary.)

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Ray. How’s it going down there?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Fine, swell, lot of interest.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: That’s terrific. Hold on, I'1l fetch your messages. She grabs a pile of messages off the desk. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) Let’s see: Gene Rafferty from United Aluminum, says he needs to reschedule Friday... Ed Nance calling again about the refund... a lady from March of Dimes about a donation... oh, and we got an order. Six.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Six?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Some drive-in out in California.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: One place? That’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: I’ve got the slip right here.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You must've misunderstood. Give me the number, I'll straighten it out. EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - SHORT TIME LATER-— Kroc pours a few nickels into the pay phone, dials a numb off his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. May I please speak to the owner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dick or Mac?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Um, whomever’s available. The guy puts the phone down, heads off. Through the recei Kroc hears the sounds of an insanely busy--and efficient- kitchen. “Order up!”... “I need six fries!"”... “Patties

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is Dick.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hello Dick, this is Ray Kroc from Prince Castle Sales. I’m phoning because someone there placed an order with us for some Multimixers.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, that was me. How soon can you get ‘em out here?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Well, that’s actually why I was calling. I believe there may have been a miscommunication between-- In the background, someone SHOUTS SOMETHING to Dick.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Freezer! Top shelf, left side! (back to Kroc) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: My secretary’s under the impression you wanted six.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You know what? I think that’s a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: That’s what I figured. What kind of drive-in would be making 30 shakes at a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better make it eight. ON KROC-- flabbergasted. Another background SHOUT. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) What’s that, Al? There’s a brand- new box in the storeroom! (to Kroc) Look, now isn’t the best time.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m still a bit--

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You know where to send ‘em, right? San Bernardino, California. Corner of 14th and E.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: To anyone in particular?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Just the store is fine. McDonald's. Another BACKGROUND SHOUT distracts Dick. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) I gotta go. Just get those mixers out here ASAP, okay? Thanks! Click. Kroc stares at the receiver. What the hell was tha EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - MOMENTS LATER Kroc stands over a U.S. ROAD MAP on the hood of his car. unfolds it, opening the map westward. (Note: This part of map is not well-worn like the Midwest; it’s virgin territ for Kroc.) Kroc’s eyes drift westward to California. They land on a small town 60 miles east of Los Angeles: San Bernardino. Kroc looks at the whole country. He notices something. A directly connecting St. Louis to San Bernardino. Route 66 ON KROC-- staring at Route 66. A single, unbroken line running from where he is now to that mysterious city out Southern California.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc driving west on Route 66. Cars, the open road, a limitless horizon. The sky, the country, the whole world seems to open up. His heart swells with possibility. The vastness excites his brain. This must be how Lewis & Clar felt. And then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc arrives in San Bernardino. A drab, dusty little town the edge of the desert. Hardly the pot of gold at the end the rainbow he was expecting. He continues along Route 66 heading toward the center of town.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Kroc driving. He sees the line before he sees the restaur A long line, hundreds of people, snaking toward a HAMBURG STAND in the distance. ON KROC-- taking in the strange sight of people out of th cars, queued up in a line leading toward a self-service window. It’s a distinctly FAMILY CROWD, lots of parents w their children. Not a teenage delinquent in sight. He parks, gets out. Unsure what to do, he gets in the lin He looks off at the restaurant, checks his watch. It’s 1:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. It moves fast. ANGLE ON the WOMAN in front of him. No sooner does she sa this than the line moves. Kroc shuffles forward 10 feet.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Kroc in line, significantly further along. He looks at hi watch. It’s 1:19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc at the front of the line. He checks his watch. 1:23.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Welcome to McDonald’s, may I take your order?  11. Kroc looks up, sees a CASHIER looking at him with a frien smile. Like all the other cashiers, he’s male and wholeso as apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Um, yes... He looks at the MENU BOARD. It has just FOUR ITEMS: burge fries, shakes, and Coca-Cola. A radical departure from th typical sprawling drive-in menu. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Hamburger, fries, and a Coca-Cola.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: 45 cents, please. Kroc hands him two quarters.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And five cents is your change. Kroc barely has time to put the nickel away when--

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here you are. The cashier hands him a paper sack. Kroc looks at it with confusion.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Your food.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I just ordered.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: (shrugs, smiles) And now it’s here. Kroc peers into the bag. Lo and behold, inside is a burge fries, and a Coca-Cola. He sees it’s all wrapped in PAPER

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: ("Where are the”--) Silverware? Plates?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: You just eat it straight out of the wrapper. Then throw it all out.  12. ON KROC-- bewildered. He takes the bag, unsure what to do

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: So now I bring it back to my car?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Most folks do. Or you could eat it in the park, at home... anywhere you like. Kroc nods. This is all so strange to him. He turns, heads toward his car. On the way, he spots an EMPTY BENCH. He impulsively takes a seat. Kroc reaches into the bag in his lap. He takes out the hamburger, noting the paper packaging. He unwraps the bur looking at it, sniffing it. It looks and smells wonderful As he’s about to take a bite, out the corner of his eye h notices in a nearby car... a GORGEOUS BLONDE. KROC’S POV: The blonde, biting into a hamburger. As she chews, a look of ecstasy comes over her face. She closes eyes, her head tipping back a bit, borderline orgasmic. ON KROC-- staring at the blonde.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: May we? Kroc is shaken out of his reverie by a FAMILY OF FOUR loo to sit on the bench. He slides over, making room.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Kroc’s attention shifts from the blonde to the family. He discretely watches as the mother passes out burgers to he two young kids. The kids bite into them, “mmm”-ing audibl ON KROC-- observing this family of four, wholesome as can devouring their delicious McDonald's hamburgers. Kroc looks at the burger in his own hand, takes a bite. A chews, his eyes roll back in his head.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How is everything? Kroc looks up, sees a MAN standing before him. His neckti and demeanor suggest manager.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: This is the best burger I ever had.  13.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: We aim to please. The man smiles, extends a friendly hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mac McDonald.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Ray Kroc. They shake. Kroc pulls a BUSINESS CARD from a pocket, han it to him. McDonald looks at it, unsure what to make of i

dialogues.speaker: CHICAGO, ILL.
dialogues.text: RAY KROC (CONT’D) The Multimixer fella.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (it clicks in--) You spoke to my brother. Mac looks again at the card, noting the Chicago address.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What brings you way out here?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh, I was just in Los Angeles. Meetings. Business. Figured as long as I was in the neighborhood, I'd swing by, say hello.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Well, I’m glad you did. Welcome! Kroc’s eyes drift to the busy, humming restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Quite an operation you got here.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Care for a little tour? There’s nothing Kroc would like more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bustling kitchen, organized as a series of stations.  14.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Speed... ON MAC-- leading Kroc through the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the name of the game. They come to a massive GRILL manned by THREE COOKS.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First stop for every McDonald's hamburger is the grill, manned by three cooks whose sole job is to grill those all-beef beauties to perfection. Kroc watches the mouth-watering beef sizzling on the gril

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile... He leads Kroc to an adjacent station, where two DRESSERS stand before a rotating Lazy Susan with 24 BUN TOPS on it

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As the patty cooks, our “dressers” get the bun ready. DRESSER #1 puts pickle slices and onion on each bun--

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every McDonald’s hamburger gets two pickles, a pinch of onion... --while DRESSER #2 applies a squirt of ketchup and mustar with a pair of trigger-operated CONDIMENT GUNS.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-and a precise shot of ketchup and mustard.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (re: condiment guns) Where'd you get those things?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We made ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Made them?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Custom built. Whole kitchen is.  15. ON KROC-- utterly amazed.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (resuming tour) Next it’s off to the finishing station... ANGLE ON the Lazy Susan, carrying 24 fully dressed bun to traveling along a belt toward a FINISHING STATION.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where it all comes together. A pair of FINISHERS put cooked patties onto the fully dre bun tops, then put on bun bottoms and neatly wrap it up.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Voila! The finished product is fed into an angled metal sleeve t slides them to the front counter, where cashiers can grab bag them with ease.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A fresh and delicious hamburger, grill to counter in 30 seconds. ON KROC-- dumbfounded by what he’s seen. He looks at Mac.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Did I come up with all of this? (sly smile) I didn’t. Kroc is confused.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We did. Kroc follows Mac’s eyes to a MAN coming toward them.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dick McDonald. My brother. Kroc grabs Dick’s hand, enthusiastically shakes.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I just have to say, what you’ve done here is nothing short of--  16.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (to Mac, ignoring Ray) The fries.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What about ‘em? Dick leads Mac toward the FRENCH FRY STATION. Kroc follow along. Dick plucks a fry off the drying rack, hands it to Mac, who pops it in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: They're five percent too crisp. Dick takes a fry, tastes it. Frowns. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) I think we should drop to two minutes, 50 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: That's what you had it at before.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: 400, not 375. Higher temp, shorter cook. Mac takes another taste.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I really think they’re spot-on.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (to Dick) If it makes any difference, they're the best fries I’ve ever tasted. Crispy golden brown on the outside, fluffy on the inside. Not too oily, perfectly salty and crunchy. Dick looks at Ray, taking note of him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: This is that Multimixer fella you spoke to.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Ray Kroc, Prince Castle Sales.  17. Kroc hands Dick his card. Dick gives it a cursory glance.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: How soon you figure we can expect ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m sending them Blue Label Air. You should have it early next week.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Good. With this, Dick abruptly walks off. Ray gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Wait! He catches up, grabs Dick’s arm. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Let me take you out to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (jokey) You're really not my type.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You and your brother. Mac, a few feet away, comes over, curious.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m gonna shoot straight with you fellas. This restaurant is the most remarkable thing I’ve seen in all my years in the food-service industry. And believe you me, I've seen it all. I want to know everything about it. Where it came from, how you thought of it. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Tell me your story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc sits across from the brothers in a corner booth, rib steaks in front of all three.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: There wasn’t a job in all of Manchester. All of New Hampshire. So we packed our bags and headed west. To Hollywood. I wanted to be in the movie business. And Dick, well, he wanted to be...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Employed.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We landed jobs driving trucks for Columbia Pictures. After a few years, we had enough saved up to buy our own little piece of show business. A little movie theater out in Glendora. Which would've been swell, except for the small matter of timing. It was September of ‘29. One minute we’re screening “Gold Diggers Of Broadway”, the next it’s “Brother, can you spare a dime?” Literally.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Nobody in town was making any money. Except this one fella, Wylie Reid. Ran a hot dog and root beer stand. People still gotta eat, right? So we decide to set up our own stand, hot dogs and orange juice, out in Arcadia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG DICK AND MAC manning their dusty, roadside HOT DO STAND during the Great Depression. A smattering of CUSTOM

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It did okay, enough to keep us off the bread line, but we were hardly doing gangbusters. There just weren’t enough people in Arcadia.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, one town over is San Bernardino, the place is growing at a terrific clip. We want to relocate, but we’ve got no money for a new stand. That’s when my brother here gets one of his brilliant ideas. Tell him, Dick. Dick throws Mac a “That’s okay, you tell him” nod.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Why don’t we move the stand we’ve got? Put it on a truck!” (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genius, right? Except one small problem. On the road between the towns, there’s an overpass. The building doesn’t clear. I figure that’s it, we’re done for. But then Dick says... Another nod of deferral from Dick.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Why don’t we saw the restaurant in half?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick and Mac driving an old flatbed Ford. On the back is stand, SPLIT IN TWO. The truck goes under an overpass, narrowly clearing.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We truck the darn thing over in two pieces, put it back together!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT-
dialogues.text: Kroc guffaws with amazement.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We move the building, set up shop. But before we open, we decide to give the place a little tweak. It’s 1940. Drive-ins are all the rage, the hottest thing going. I say Dick, we gotta get in on this. Dick says sure. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two months later, we open for business... (show-biz hands) “McDonald’s Famous Barbecue!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers’ proto-McDonald’s, up and running. Pretty CARHOPS in tasseled short skirts and Western boots hustle about serving customers.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We've got a 27-item menu, barbecue slow-cooked in a real pit out back. Uniformed waitresses bring the food straight out to your car. It does gangbusters. Going great guns. But then, sales start to level off.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: The drive-in model, as we learn, has a few built-in problems. Kroc leans in, eager to hear their take on this. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) For starters, there’s the customer issue. Drive-ins tend to attract, shall we say, a less-than desirable clientele.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Hot rodders and hooligans. Juvenile delinquents in blue jeans. Kroc nods, all too familiar. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) Then there’s the service. It takes forever and a day for your food to arrive. And when it finally does--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s completely wrong.  Kroc nods. 21.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: The carhops are too busy dodging gropes to remember you wanted a strawberry phosphate, not cherry.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: If they remember at all.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Then there’s the expenses. Payroll is high due to the large staff required. Dishes are constantly getting stolen or broken.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Tremendous overhead.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: But one day Dick has a realization. Going over the books, he notices something. The bulk of our sales come from just three items: Burgers, fries, soft drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: 87 percent.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We say to ourselves, what the heck are we doing monkeying around with all this other stuff? Focus on what sells. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that’s just what we do. Brisket, gone. Tamales, gone. And we don’t stop at the menu. We look at everything. What else don’t we need?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Turns out, quite a lot.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Carhops.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Walk up to a window. Get your food yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Dishes.  22.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: All paper packaging. Disposable.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Jukeboxes, cigarette machines.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Drive out the riff-raff.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (totally in sync) Create a family-friendly environment!

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: And finally, the biggest, most important cut of all... the wait.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Orders ready in 30 seconds, not 30 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We decide to tear down the kitchen. Rebuild. Reconfigure. Rethink the whole dang thing. And you're gonna love how we do it. Tell him, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: The tennis court?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He brings me out to this tennis court, draws an outline in the dirt. Exact dimensions of our kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TENNIS COURT, somewhere in San Bernardino. Mac watches Dick carefully draws a KITCHEN OUTLINE on it with a stick

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We bring in a bunch of employees, have ‘em go through the motions, making pretend burgers and fries. --An invisible kitchen, YOUNG EMPLOYEES mimicking the mov trying to get it right.  23.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dick’s chasing after them with the stick, marking up where all the equipment should go. They do it over and over, hashing out the moves, choreographing like it’s some sort of crazy burger ballet. --Over and over. It’s starting to get dark.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Finally, after about six hours of this, we get it just right. --Workers making pretend burgers and fries in perfect syn

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A symphony of efficiency. Not a wasted motion.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We take the layout to a builder, custom build to exact specs.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Ta-da. The Speedee System is born. The world’s first-ever system designed to deliver food fast. It's totally revolutionary.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: And a complete disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grand opening. The hungry and the curious pulling up.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Opening day, people pull into the lot, immediately start honking when no carhop comes over. We try to explain the walk-up window. They're bewildered. Furious. “Whaddaya mean I gotta get out of my car?”  24.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Most of them just cuss us out and drive off. The few that stick around are mad as heck about having to eat off paper and discard their own trash.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We may have underestimated the learning curve.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: By five o'clock, Dick’s calculating the cost of converting back to drive-in. But me, I’m not quite ready to throw in the towel. Going back to my Hollywood roots, I say to myself, “We gotta go big with this. We gotta put on a show.” I tell Dick I want to throw a grand re-opening. A gala premiere to put Louis B. Mayer to shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fast-food equivalent of a Hollywood-style premiere.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We rent a bunch of spotlights, the same ones we used to truck around to premieres in the Columbia days. I get sparklers, a juggler for the kiddies--it’s an event. People show up in droves. And then...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The flies. --An ominous cloud gathers over the restaurant. A SWARM O INSECTS. They swoop down in unison, as if in attack mode.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They must've been drawn by all the lights.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Millions of ‘em. Looked like something out of Exodus. --Customers running, screaming. Swatting.  25.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Pharaoh would’ve released the Israelites.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s a total disaster. Towel time. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning, Dick and I meet up to discuss going back to the old format. As we're talking, there’s a knock at the service window. Dick goes over, sees a little boy standing there. He wants a bag of burgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick at the service window, looking at a YOUNG KID. His n barely clears the counter.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I tell him we're closed.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But he’s cute, I feel bad for him, so I fire up the grill, make hima batch. And as he’s heading off... --A car pulls into the lot.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A car pulls up. --A second car.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then another. --A third car.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And another. Before you know it, there’s a line around the block. --A LINE OF CUSTOMERS stretching into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Word has spread.  26.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: And it’s off to the races.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We’re an overnight sensation. Thirty years in the making. ON KROC-- absorbing all of this, blown away. Mac gives Kroc a modest little shrug.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So that’s our story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc lies awake in bed, buzzing, unable to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick and Mac pull into the McDonald’s lot in Dick’s car. They’re startled to see-- Kroc, sitting out front. He approaches their car. Before can fully roll down his window:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Franchise.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Beg pardon?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Franchise, franchise the thing. It’s too good to just be one location. There ought to be McDonald's everywhere. Coast to coast, sea to shining sea. And I’m just the man to help you do it. I’ve spent the better part of my life criss-crossing this country. I know every highway and byway, every city and every town.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Mr. Kroc...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Let me just say one thing. One more thing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to confess something to you boys. I’m not out here in California on any business meeting. I’m out here for you. You’re what brought me out. A few days ago, I was standing outside a filling station in St. Louis, Missouri staring at a U.S. road map, staring at a long, white, unbroken line called Route 66. I took my finger--

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Mr. Kroc-—

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I took my finger, and I traced that line from where I was standing all the way out to California, where it ran smack-dab into this place we are now. As I stared at that line, something told me to follow it. Something told me to get in my car and see what’s out there at the other end. And when I laid eyes on your hamburger stand yesterday, all those people lined up to purchase your remarkable product, I knew it was-—-

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We already tried!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc and the brothers stand before a U.S. MAP.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Five. ANGLE ON map. Five PUSH PINS are stuck in it, clustered around California and the Southwest. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) Three in Southern California, one in Sacramento and one in Phoenix. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that’s all there’1ll ever be.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Why?  28.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Two words: Quality control. It’s almost impossible to enforce standards from afar.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Those places were a mess. Filthy kitchens, inconsistent menus...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Sacramento was selling burritos.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: To watch your precious creation get mismanaged like that. Your name.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Put Mac in the hospital. Kroc looks at Mac, surprised. A BEAT as

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Diabetes and extreme stress don’t mix. Kroc absorbs this.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: But if you had somebody in charge of supervising.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He obviously didn’t do a great job.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: So replace him. With someone better.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Our energies are better spent making this place the best it can possibly be.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Better one great restaurant than 50 mediocre ones.  29.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Sure, but I still think if you had the right--

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Thank you, we’re not interested.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Someone as committed to quality as--

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Thank you. Kroc backs off. A BEAT of awkward silence. Kroc’s eye goes to something else on the wall... a BLUEPR The building has towering arches on each side.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: A blueprint.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Those: Mac follows Kroc’s eyes to the arches.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s a way to make the place stand out when you’re driving past.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: “The Golden Arches” I call ‘em. Kroc stares at them, fascinated. It’s a crazy, radical (a kind of brilliant) thing to stick on the sides of a build

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Who thought of that?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: That’s pure Dick magic right there. Dick’s gaze is still on the arches, clearly proud.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Ever do one like that?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Just one...  30. Dick looks at the U.S. map. A lonely push pin in the midd of Arizona. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) Phoenix. EXT. ROUTE 66 - SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA/ARIZONA -— DAY Kroc driving back along Route 66, taking in the scenery. SERIES OF SHOTS: Kroc passing through various small towns each with a Main Street running through it. On every Main Street, we see the same two things: a church and courthou Glimpses of various churches and courthouses. Churches to with crosses. Courthouses with American flags. ON KROC-- processing, wheels turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc driving through Flagstaff. He passes a road sign: I-

dialogues.speaker: SOUTH
dialogues.text: He takes an impulsive detour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc drives down Phoenix’s Central Avenue. He sees the ar before he sees the restaurant. Kroc pulls into the empty lot (the restaurant is closed). gets out, looks up at the arches. They’re lit up and glow Glorious, magical. He does a slow lap around the building, taking in the arc from all angles. Halfway around, the shifting perspective causes the arches to meet. They form a giant “M” (the McDonald's logo as we know it today), 30 feet high. ON KROC-- standing before the “M”, bathed in its golden, glowing light. Like Moses before the Burning Bush. EXT. KROC’S HOUSE (DES PLAINES, IL) - DAY A modest home in the Chicago suburbs. Kroc pulls up in hi car.  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ETHEL (53) is at the table, eating dinner by herself.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ethel! Kroc comes bursting in, burning with excitement. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I’ve seen the future! Ethel’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I saw a restaurant, Ethel. It’s like nothing you’ve ever seen. They've got this system, the Speedee System...

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Ray...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Just hear me out.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I’m too old for this.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: This place, it’s like something sprung from the mind of Henry--

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I can’t do it. Not again.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to be a part of greatness?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I want to be part of a cruise. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All our friends are taking trips, enjoying their golden years. And us, we're still scrapping and scraping like a couple of 25-year- olds. When do we get to start living, Ray? When do we finally get to start enjoying our lives?  This sets 32.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Ethel, this place--

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: It’s revolutionary.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (bristles at her sarcasm) As a matter of fact...

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: It’s never going to get any better, Ray. We’re never going to have anything more than we have right now. And that’s okay. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s not okay is us wasting our lives reaching for some brass ring we're never going to grab.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (flash of anger) Maybe if I had a wife who had an ounce of vision. Who gave me an ounce of support.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Support? Support? her off-- ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) All I’ve done is support you! I’ve had your back through thick and thin, through one cockamamie idea after another. The wax cups, the Fold-A-Nook, the Multi-Mixer, on and on, every last one. And you have the nerve to say I don’t support you?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (backing off, chastened) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I’ve believed in you, Ray. Our whole marriage. Long past the point any rational, thinking person would've.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You're right.  33.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I’ve sacrificed, I’ve saved. Made do, gone without. My belt’s so tight, I’m out of notches.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: “Support”? (BEAT )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you? Kroc just stands there in shamed little-boy silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc steps to the ticket window.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: One ticket, please. The marquees reads MAGNIFICENT OBSESSION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc sits in the theater, the light of the screen flicker off his face. In his hand is his flask. He takes a discre swig. INT. PRINCE CASTLE SALES - KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS June Martino watches Kroc pace, ringing phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: McDonald’s Hamburgers.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Dick McDonald, please.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s not available at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Mac, then. The employee puts the phone down, goes off to check. Thro it, Kroc hears what sounds like a BIG CROWD.  34.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, he’ll have to call you back. We’re real busy right now. Kroc glances at his watch, puzzled by the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What time is it there?

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: 10 o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (thrown ) What time do you open?

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ll. ON KROC-- amazed. They don’t even open for another hour. INT. JOHNSON’S DRIVE-IN - KITCHEN - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc out on a drive-in sales call, giving his standard sp

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (flat, distracted) Mr. Johnson, are you familiar with the notion of the chicken and the egg? I mention it because I think it’s applicable here. EXT. JOHNSON’S DRIVE-IN - PARKING LOT - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc hauls the sample Multimixer back to his car, shoves in the trunk. He takes a swig from his flask, staring off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc steps to the TWA ticket counter.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: One ticket to Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dinner rush. Mac and Dick hustle about making sure th run as smoothly as possible. ON DICK-- reloading the Lazy Susan with bun tops.  35.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do it for your country.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (turns, surprised) Ray.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Mac is there, too.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: If you boys don’t want to franchise for yourselves, fine. But do it for your country. For America. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place you’ve created, it’s not a restaurant. It’s not even a place. It’s an idea. ON DICK-- absorbing.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (to nearby employee) Tommy, finish the buns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc stands before the brothers.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: That drive back home on 66, I passed through a lot of towns. A lot of small towns. In the middle of each one of them was a Main Street. And on each of those Main Streets were always the same two things: a courthouse and a church. A courthouse topped with a flag. A church topped with a cross. Flags and crosses, crosses and flags. The brothers look at each other, unsure where this is goi RAY KROC (CONT’D) As I drove along, I pondered those crosses and flags. I asked myself why they’re so ubiquitous. What they mean. And as I did, I couldn’t help but think about your restaurant. About these--  36. He goes over to the blueprint, plants a finger on the arc RAY KROC (CONT’D) Now, forgive me if this flirts with blasphemy, but to my mind, these arches share a great deal in common with the Christian cross and the American flag. A building topped with a cross is a gathering place. A place where decent, wholesome folks can come together and be with others who share their values. The same can be said of a building flanked by a pair of your arches. Those arches mean more than simply “delicious hamburgers inside”. They signify family. Community. The ties that bind. They represent goodness, togetherness, a place for Americans to gather and break bread. McDonald’s can be that, too. The new American church, feeding bodies and feeding souls. And not just on Sundays. Seven days a week. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crosses. Flags. Arches. ON MAC-- blown away. He looks over at Dick, expecting a similar reaction. He’s surprised to see a conflicted look his face.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (to Kroc) Would you please give us a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers, alone in the office.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (tempted, torn) I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s your dream, Dick. (eye contact) Bigger than your dream. Arches-- your arches--coast to coast. Dick’s eyes go to the U.S. map. A whole country, just wai to be filled in with push pins.  37.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I can’t put you through that again. ON MAC-- looking at Dick gazing longingly at the map.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I know how bad you want this. You should have it.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Last time, you very nearly wound up—

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We'll do it different this time. Learn from our mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We keep a much tighter leash. Total oversight, every change has to go through us.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Who says he’s gonna listen?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We draw up a contract. Lay it out, clear as day in black and white. ON DICK-- pondering. Seemingly warming to the idea.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whaddaya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Kroc sits across a table from the brothers and their LAWYER. Kroc is skimming through a BIG FAT CONTRACT. Full clauses and sections and paragraphs. ANGLE ON contract. Amidst a wall of legalese:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fine.  38. Kroc has a rushed air about him, eager to get to the dott line. He continues skimming. A glimpse of another page:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Three copies of the contract are laid out before Kroc, op to the last page. The brothers’ lawyer slides him a fount pen. He readily signs in triplicate.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: We are a dynamic, fast-growing company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc, dressed in his best suit and tie, sits across from LOAN OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: And now, we’re poised to make major inroads nationally. The loan officer looks at a set of BLUEPRINTS on his desk titled MCDONALD'S #6 - DES PLAINES, ILL. RAY KROC (CONT’D) In addition to giving us a foothold in the Midwest, the Des Plaines location will serve as a lure for prospective franchisees. The loan officer looks over the blueprint. Something catc his eye.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: What are those? Kroc follows his gaze to the arches. He smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s just my little way of separating us from the pack. “The Golden Arches”, I call ‘em.  39. The loan officer picks up a bound prospectus prepared by Kroc. Artist renderings, projected earnings, etc. ON KROC-- anxiously watching as he leafs through it. RAY KROC (CONT’D) (filling the air) There’s nothing like it in the entire food-service sector. The loan officer looks up from the materials.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: You look familiar. Have we met?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (a drop uneasy) I don’t believe so. ON LOAN OFFICER, staring, determined to place the face. H snaps his fingers--

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: The Fold-A-Nook! (hint of smirk) “It’s Like A Murphy Bed... For Your Kitchen!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc exits the bank in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc sits across from another LOAN OFFICER, watching as h looks over the prospectus.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: There’s nothing like it in the entire food-service sector. The officer looks up at Kroc.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Have we met? The man searches his face. Kroc squirms. LOAN OFFICER #2 (CONT’D) The paper-cup guy. ON KROC-- silent a long beat.  40.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, broken) Among many other things. The loan officer stares at Kroc, taking in his vulnerable Willy Loman-esque visage. A wave of compassion/pity comes over him.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: I tell you what. Let me refer you to one of my colleagues. Somebody who may be better suited to meet your needs.

dialogues.speaker: A FEW DESKS DOWN
dialogues.text: Kroc sits before a different LOAN OFFICER. The man is fil out an APPLICATION FORM for Kroc.

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Address?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: 143 Juniper Road, Arlington Heights, Illinois. ANGLE ON the form as the man fills in Kroc’s address. It’ HOME-MORTGAGE LOAN APPLICATION. A desk plaque tells us th is HARVEY PELTZ - HOME MORTGAGE REPRESENTATIVE.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: Home telephone number?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Let me give you my office number. Kroc glances at his WEDDING RING. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That’s the best place to reach me. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY ANGLE ON blueprints for the Des Plaines McDonald's coveri Kroc’s walls.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you schedule the stakeout with the engineer?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All set.  41. ON KROC-- at his desk, plowing through a lengthy to-do li as June takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Where are we at on fire department approval for driveway design?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Left a message yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Call again. Excavation permit?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Meeting with them today.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Insurers?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: I left a message yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Call again. What about the zoning office?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: All set. On file with the city.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: San Bernardino?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: I just spoke to Dick. He says they're working on it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Working on it? He lets out a heaving, irritated sigh. RAY KROC (CONT’D) It’s been a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick is at his desk. An EMPLOYEE sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: Ray Kroc, line one.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Hiya, Ray.  42.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You boys are killing me. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS (Intercut as necessary.)

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What’s the hold up? I break ground in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: These things take time. You're proposing substantial alterations.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m adding a basement and furnace.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We need our architect to thoroughly review it to make sure everything's safe and up to code.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Has he looked at it yet?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I can’t afford to let this drag.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Ray, you need to take a breath. It hasn’t even been a week.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’ve got bulldozers rolling up on the 23rd.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I’m not the one who scheduled that.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what it’d cost me to push?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Hopefully, it won’t come to that.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Every restaurant in the Midwest has a basement and a furnace. This is standard stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I understand. But you have to understand, it’s our name on that building. God forbid the floor caves in and people get hurt or worse because of some design flaw we missed, we’re the ones on the hook. So let’s just slow down a minute and make sure it’s done the right way. Alright? pondering Dick’s words of reason.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: So much for the Speedee System! He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Mac is in the office with Dick.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Then what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He slammed down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He hung up on you?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Unless we got violently disconnected. Dick looks off, feeling the first pangs of buyer’s remors

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON a sign: COMING SOON - MCDONALD’S FAMOUS HAMBURGE A hard-hatted Kroc stands in a dirt lot, watching SURVEYO outline a building foundation. He heads over to one of th surveyors, pointing to some detail--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Can we bring that out another foot?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir? June comes over to Kroc with a letter. He looks at it, se the San Bernardino return address.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Read it. She opens the letter, reads aloud--

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: “Dear Ray, Thank you for your letter sharing your idea to strike a deal with Coca-Cola to sponsor menu boards at the new Des Plaines location. An intriguing notion, indeed. As you rightly point out, such an arrangement would provide a steady source of revenue to the store at no additional labor cost. ON KROC-- pleased with the letter so far. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) “However...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc is on a pay phone across the street from the construction site.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Small, along the bottom. Very discrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other end is Mac in the kitchen, his brother nearb (Intercut as necessary.)

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Ray, but we’re just not comfortable with the notion of turning our menu into an advertisement.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Not an ad. Sponsorship.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s distasteful.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s free money.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: There are plenty of things we could do to make a quick buck, but that doesn’t mean we should.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Loads of restaurants do it.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Well, we don’t.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Because I have no interest in indulging in that sort of crass commercialism. It’s not McDonald's.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I didn’t realize I was partnering up with a beatnik.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I happen to be a card-carrying Republican.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You coulda fooled me! He slams down the phone. Again.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Mac and Dick, post-call.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He’s just a little... excitable.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: A hothead like that, you don’t know what he’s capable of.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s all bluster, Dick. His bark is worse than his bite.  46.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (dark chuckle) That’s what Neville Chamberlain said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brand-new Des Plaines McDonald's, up and running. TRACKING SHOT, high-energy, as Kroc moves through the KIT barking out orders to his charges. It’s a bit militaristi vibe, echoing Dick’s Hitler reference: “Watch those fries!”... “Straighten that hat!”... “Buns t the left, pickles to the right!”... “Let’s go, boys!” He passes an EMPLOYEE, catching him in a moment of repose

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Grab a mop! If there’s time to lean, there’s time to clean! Tracking shot ends at the GRILL, manned by a trio of GRIL overseeing dozens of patties. Kroc moves down the line: GRILLER #1, flipping a patty-- RAY KROC (CONT’D) More wrist! Kroc grabs the spatula, demonstrates proper form. He move onto GRILLER #2, who’s lifting a patty off the grill-- RAY KROC (CONT’D) It’s still pink! Kroc puts the patty back onto the grill. He moves on to

dialogues.speaker: GRILLER
dialogues.text: RAY KROC (CONT’D) What the heck are you-- Kroc trails off, realizing Griller #3 is doing NOTHING WR His patties are perfect, arranged in rows so precise they could have been lined up with a ruler. ON KROC-- taking in the eager young buck, who looks maybe RAY KROC (CONT’D) What’s your name?  47.

dialogues.speaker: GRILLER
dialogues.text: Fred Turner, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Fred Turner... (small, approving nod) Keep it up.

dialogues.speaker: FRED TURNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Kroc walks off. Turner is thrilled by the approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the glow of the arches, Kroc scours the parking lot fanatically cleaning. Picking up discarded cups, scraping off the underside of benches. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - LATER Ethel is asleep in bed. Kroc enters, home from another lo day of work. He starts getting undressed. As he unbuttons his shirt, he hears a sound. A tiny sniff Ethel is awake, crying softly. He goes over, sits on the bed next to her.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. ON KROC-- taking in her sad, lonely face. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I know I’ve neglected you. He looks her in the eye. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Tomorrow night. Let’s have supper at the club.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: (surprised, heartened) Really?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s been far too long. He hands her a tissue. She blows her nose.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room of a not especially upscale country club. Kroc leads Ethel to a big round table. At it are fellow C MEMBERS, who warmly greet them.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: By George, I think I’ve seen a ghost!

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: The middle of the meal. Ray kibitzes with the men, Ethel engaged in a cross-conversation with the wives.

dialogues.speaker: CLUB WIFE
dialogues.text: I hear Acapulco is divine.

dialogues.speaker: CLUB WIFE
dialogues.text: Mildred Ballard was just there. She adored it. Ethel nods along, not wanting to stick out. CLUB WIFE #2 (CONT’D) Where do you like, Ethel?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Me? (BEAT, scrambling) Spain.

dialogues.speaker: CLUB WIFE
dialogues.text: Wonderful! How was it?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: (backtracks ) I mean, we're thinking about it. Planning to, in the fall. Nods and smiles from the other women. The conversation mo on, bullet dodged.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: That's the last time I try a sand wedge in that bunker! Hearty laughs from the others, loving the golf humor.

dialogues.speaker: JACK HORFORD
dialogues.text: How's your game, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Lately? Non-existent. The men laugh, missing the literalness of the statement.

dialogues.speaker: JACK HORFORD
dialogues.text: I’m no Ben Hogan myself. ON KROC-- seeing an opening in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (cryptic smile) But I did recently hit a hole-in- one of a different sort. The men glance at each other, intrigued. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Anyone interested in hearing about an exciting investment opportunity? Kroc sneaks a glance at Ethel. She’s staring at him, crestfallen. So this is why we’re at the club.

dialogues.speaker: JACK HORFORD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (chuckle) Here we go again... ON HORFORD-- smiling at Kroc, a bit condescendingly. JACK HORFORD (CONT’D) What is it this time, Ray? ON ETHEL-- taking in the way Horford looks at her husband irks her.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Hear him out. Ethel looks at Ray, looks back at Horford. ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) This is different. ON KROC-- surprised and touched she has his back. He grab her hand under the table, looks her reassuringly in the e Yes, it is. It is different this time.  50.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: --Jerry Cullen signing franchise papers as Kroc looks on. --Kroc and Jack Horford, in hardhats, presiding as ground broken at a CONSTRUCTION SITE. Behind them is a sign with McDonald’s mascot Speedee, who says, “HOWDY, SCHAUMBURG! McDONALD’S IS ON THE WAY!” --Kroc and Ethel having dinner again at Rolling Green CC, Kroc working the menfolk, trolling for franchisees. --Kroc playing a round of golf at the club, giving his go mates the sales spiel. --Kroc looking on as one of the golf guys signs a contrac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc pulls into the parking lot of Jack Horford’s brand-n Schaumburg McDonald's. There’s a line out front, not spectacular but solid. He parks, heads toward the restaurant. He slows, noticing something. KROC’S POV: A patron in his car, biting into a hamburger. Sticking out the sides of the burger is a PIECE OF LETTUC ON KROC-- staring at the lettuce, disturbed by the sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Horford, part of a foursome, is about to tee off.

dialogues.speaker: GOLF BUDDY
dialogues.text: Give it a whack, Jack. Horford rears back to swing when, out the corner of his e he sees-- KROC, storming onto the course, marching toward him. As Kroc gets closer, Horford sees he’s holding something. a HAMBURGER. Kroc gets right up in his face with it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What is this? Horford stares at the burger.  51.

dialogues.speaker: JACK HORFORD
dialogues.text: It appears to be a hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s not a McDonald’s hamburger. He lifts off the bun, pointing out its myriad deficiencie RAY KROC (CONT’D) Too much ketchup. Three pickles not two. Lettuce. Lettuce, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK HORFORD
dialogues.text: Do you think we could discuss this later? We’re in the middle of--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: And the patty. (breaks it open) Tragically overcooked.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Ray... Fellow franchise owner Jerry Cullen (part of the foursome leans in, checking out the burger. JERRY CULLEN (CONT’D) Looks good to me.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (glares at Cullen) What the heck would you know about quality? ON CULLEN-- thrown. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I dropped in on your store today. I must say, I was quite disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: What by?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: For starters, the menu... Corn on the cob?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with corn on the cob?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Fried chicken?  52.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: People love fried chicken.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Then they can go to a restaurant that serves it! Cullen and Horford trade glances, bewildered. RAY KROC (CONT’D) And the filth. The kitchen looked like some sort of Manchurian slum.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: (smirk) With great chicken. Everybody laughs. Kroc is not amused.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (to both of them) Are you aware of what goes on at your restaurants? Do you even care?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: Look, Ray, I don’t know about you, but I’m retired.

dialogues.speaker: JACK HORFORD
dialogues.text: You said this’d be a good place to park our money. It’s an investment, nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY CULLEN
dialogues.text: If I wanted a job, I'da applied for a cook position. ON KROC-- silently stewing. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Ethel is getting dressed, putting on jewelry and makeup. enters, home from work.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Hurry up and get changed. Dinner’s called for seven.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: We’re not going to the club tonight.  53.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: You cancelled our dinner plans?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I cancelled our membership.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Those Rolling Green people aren’t our kind.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’ve lost interest in hobnobbing with the idle rich.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Idle rich?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: With their golf and their Rob Roys.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Please tell me this is a joke.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Contented. Complacent.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Those are my friends, Ray. My entire social life!

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: We'll find new friends. Ethel throws herself onto the bed, bursting into tears. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Far more suitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc sits in his car across the street from Jack Horford’ McDonald's, anonymously watching-- KROC’S POV: A crowd of ANNOYED CUSTOMERS waiting for thei food. A customer checks his watch.  54.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: (to cashier) How much longer? Kroc watches the shabbily run operation, sickened. He tak swig from his flask. The pre-lap sound of VOMITING carries over to-- INT. PRINCE CASTLE SALES - MEN’S ROOM - DAY Kroc bent over the toilet, puking his guts out. INT. OFFICE —- MOMENTS LATER Kroc exits the bathroom, walks toward the FRONT DESK carr the men’s room key.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just take a gander at this handsome gold inlay. Kroc comes to the desk, where he sees a BIBLE SALESMAN (2 talking to June, briefcase full of samples popped open.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're telling me such spectacular craftsmanship isn’t worth $8.95?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Thank you, I’m not interested.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Not interested in a Bible sure to be the pride of your home library? ON KROC-- observing the young salesman.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you no doubt know, June, envy is one of the seven deadly sins. And that’s just what your friends and neighbors will be guilty of when they see this leather-bound beauty on your bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Sir, this is a private place of business. I’m afraid I’m going to have to ask you to leave.  55. BEAT. The salesman gathers up his things, heads out of th office. June’s telephone rings. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) Prince Castle Sales. (BEAT, listening) Oh, hello, Mac. Kroc hears the name. A knot instantly forms in his stomac JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) One moment, I’1l see if he’s in. She covers the phone, turns to Kroc. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) It’s Mac... just wants to know how it’s going. ON KROC-- frozen, staring at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salesman heading down the hall toward the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait! The salesman slows, turns. Standing there is Kroc, lookin him over, sizing him up. RAY KROC (CONT’D) What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Leonard. Leonard Rosenblatt.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Rosenblatt. ON KROC-- digesting the name, intrigued. RAY KROC (CONT’D) What’s a Jew doing selling Catholic Bibles?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD ROSENBLATT
dialogues.text: (unapologetic) Making a living. ON KROC-- taking in the hungry young go-getter. It’s not to read his mind. This is just the sort of fella I need.  56. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Rosenblatt and his wife MYRA (22) sit across from Kroc. K slides a pen and contract to them. ON LEONARD AND MYRA ROSENBLATT-- looking at each other. Excited, hopeful. A young couple, staking everything on a shared dream. Myra gives his hand a squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: MYRA ROSENBLATT
dialogues.text: I believe in you.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD ROSENBLATT
dialogues.text: Us, Myra. ON KROC-- watching the interaction with admiration--and a touch of jealousy. EXT. MCDONALD'S (THE ROSENBLATTS’) - DAY (A FEW MONTHS LA The Rosenblatts’ new McDonald's in Waukegan, IL. Festive bunting lines the front, a banner proclaiming GRAND OPENI TODAY! A line of the curious and hungry forms outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hustle and bustle of a smooth-running kitchen. It’s a model of cleanliness and professionalism, everything the country clubbers’ locations were not. ON KROC-- in the middle of it all, observing, highly plea

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD ROSENBLATT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let’s go, chop-chop! ON ROSENBLATT-- moving around the kitchen, barking out orders, making sure everything’s just so.

dialogues.speaker: MYRA ROSENBLATT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Here y’go, champ! Kroc looks toward the front of the store, where he sees.. Myra, handing out lollipops to children. She’s wearing a apron that says MCDONALD’S--and a big smile on her face. Kroc goes over. She hands him a lollipop. MYRA ROSENBLATT (CONT’D) It’s normally ten and under, but for you I’1l make an exception.  57. Kroc looks at the lollipop. Tied to it is a ribbon with t store’s address on it. He couldn’t be more impressed.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: You shoulda seen ‘em. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - THAT NIGHT Kroc is getting undressed for bed, buzzing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You've never seen a pair of dynamos like these two. ON ETHEL-- in bed, half-listening, about to fall asleep. RAY KROC (CONT’D) He’s in back, running the kitchen, she’s up front, passing out suckers to the kiddies. Like a real team. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s wonderful. Don’t you think? No reply from the sleepy Ethel. He gives her a poke. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Don’t I what?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Think it’s wonderful. (angling) Two people, side by side, working together...

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Are you trying to hire me, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You say you never see me anymore. This is a perfect way.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I don’t want to work for you.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: With me. Husband and wife, united in labor and in life. You know?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I mean...  58. ON ETHEL-- pondering, really struggling with the notion. ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) Not really. A stretch of tense, edgy silence.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I made us supper plans for Friday.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose you rejoined Rolling Green.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: No. (gazes off) Someplace far better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON a big banner across a wood-paneled wall: VFW POS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN DOWN to a long table lined with couples. Blue-collar types, several rungs down the social ladder from Rolling Green. And younger, average age closer to 30 than 60. In the midst of them, we find Ray and Ethel. They’re dres deliberately “blue collar”, matching the people around th ON ETHEL-- edgily pushing her meatloaf and mashed potatoe around her plate.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, Art, what do you do for a living? Kroc is chatting up the COUPLE (mid-20s) next to them.

dialogues.speaker: ART WOLODARSKY
dialogues.text: Well, I had a little plumbing business going for a while after getting out of the service. Now I sell vacuum cleaners. And give piano lessons on the side.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Golly. Plumbing, pianos, you're a regular jack of all trades.

dialogues.speaker: ART WOLODARSKY
dialogues.text: Whatever puts food on the table.  59. Art’s WIFE smiles proudly at her hard-working man. ON KROC-- sizing them up. They fit the profile to a T.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: How would you like to do more than merely “put food on the table”?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. KROC’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Art Wolodarsky signing up for a franchise, his faithful w by his side. This leads to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc hunting for new recruits for the McDonald's Army. Qu cuts of Kroc making the SAME SPEECH in various places. Shriners halls, synagogues, Amway meetings:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m looking for a few good men! Hustlers! Scrappers! Grinders! Men willing to roll up their sleeves, men with fire in their bellies! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stand before you today offering something more precious than gold: opportunity. Opportunity to advance. To succeed. To get your shot at the brass ring, the American Dream. For McDonald's, like this great nation itself, is a true meritocracy. If you’re willing to put in the work, if you’ve got the gumption and the guts and the desire, the sky’s the limit at McDonald's. Put in the necessary elbow grease and, by gum, I promise you there’s a pot of gold waiting for you at the end of those Golden Arches. So who’s with me? Who's ready to strap it on and step onto that first rung of the ladder of success? Who’s ready to make that glorious upward climb, ascending into the hard-won heavens of success and prosperity? Shots of Kroc gaining traction, getting on a roll:  60. --YOUNG COUPLES cashing out bank accounts. --Kroc cutting the ribbon at store openings. Lines down t block. Cash registers ringing. --Kroc biting into a burger served by the owner-operator new franchise. Art Wolodarsky. --Kroc driving back to his own store in Des Plaines, swee the lot after dark.
