Relentless. Inexhaustible. Obsessed. END OF MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flight in mid-air. Kroc, in a window seat, gazes out at flat, snow-dusted expanse below. Next to him is Fred Turn head buried in a McDonald's operations manual.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we are about to begin our initial descent into Minneapolis-St. Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc and Turner pull up to a brand-new McDonald’s in a ta Stretched across the front is a banner: MINNESOTA IS MCDONALD’S COUNTRY! They step out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Welcome! JIM ZIEN, the store’s burly, gregarious owner, comes out greet them. With a showman’s flourish, he gestures to a p of HIGH-SCHOOL CHEERLEADERS in McDonald's red and white.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gimme an M!

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN
dialogues.text: Gimme a C!

dialogues.speaker: CHEERLEADERS
dialogues.text: Cc! ON KROC-- beaming, eating up the red-carpet reception.  61.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gimme a D!

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: INT. ROLLIE’S STEAKHOUSE - LATER/EVENING Kroc, Turner and Zien at a Minneapolis steakhouse. The WA is taking their orders.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Ribeye. Bloody. (hands waiter menu, smiles) I want the cow still mooing. Everybody chuckles. Kroc is really feeling his oats. RAY KROC (CONT’D) And a couple sides of creamed spinach for the table.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Kroc is tucking into his enormous, bloody steak.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN
dialogues.text: How is it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You couldn't top this in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN
dialogues.text: We don’t mess around up here.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: My compliments to the chef.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN
dialogues.text: I’1l do you one better. How about the owner? With this, Zien waves at someone across the room. A MAN c over, gives Zien a chummy back-pat.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Jimmy! Good to see ya! We get the distinct sense this was pre-arranged.  62.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything alright tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN
dialogues.text: Wonderful as always, Rollie. Zien gestures toward his VIP guest--

dialogues.speaker: JIM ZIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rollie Smith, Ray Kroc. This is ROLLIE SMITH, the owner. He enthusiastically shak Kroc’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You’ve got one helluva restaurant here.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Coming from you, that’s quite a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (pleased) I see my reputation precedes me.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: I’m a great admirer. Kroc gestures to an empty chair, eager for more flattery. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) (fake-demurring) I don’t want to interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Maybe just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: ONE HOUR LATER--
dialogues.text: A BUSBOY is clearing plates. Smith is still at the table. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) Well, you’ve certainly found a warm and loving home here in Minneapolis.  63.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: So it seems.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: This town just can’t get enough of McDonald's. Smith raises Kroc’s empty glass to a passing WAITER. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) Another Canadian Club for my friend. The waiter nods, heads off with the glass. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) (resuming-- ) In fact, I'd say there’s sufficient enthusiasm to support another.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: A second location?

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: And come to think of it, I can think of the perfect person to own and operate.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (gamely playing along) You don’t say.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Somebody who knows what it takes to build a great restaurant. Someone with more than 25 years experience in the food-service industry.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Me!

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh! ON KROC-- deeply enjoying this. For a man who’s spent his life groveling, sucking up to people, trying to curry fav to be on the receiving end is a thrilling new experience.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: I’ve got the know-how. I’ve got the backers. And I’ve got the location.  64. A PIANO is heard in the background. Light, lovely tinklin

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with Hennepin Avenue? ON KROC-- distracted, looking toward the piano. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) It’s one of the busiest commercial arteries in the whole Twin Cities. There's a prime site that recently became available, a full acre on the corner of Hennepin and... (sees Kroc not listening) Mr. Kroc? Kroc is staring off, transfixed. Smith follows his gaze t An ATTRACTIVE BLONDE, early 30s, playing a BABY GRAND PIA in the corner. Smith watches Kroc watch her, clearly smit ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) Would you like to meet her? This gets Kroc’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER-
dialogues.text: Smith is at the piano, leaning in to the woman’s ear, say something. She gets up, goes over to the table with him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Ray Kroc, meet Joan Smith. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Joan is sitting next to Kroc, hanging on his every word.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: ..-Milwaukee, Kenosha, Grand Rapids and the three Chicago area.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Goodness.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh, and Dayton, Ohio.  65.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: All in the last 12 months?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Nine.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Nine? You must be positively dizzy, Mr. Kroc!

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Please. Call me Ray.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: (eye contact, purr) Ray... Kroc blushes, defenseless against the ego-stroking of a pretty blonde.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: That’s some growth.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: When did you start it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (caught off guard) Hm?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: What year, did you start McDonald's? BEAT. Kroc looks at Joan looking at him. So beautiful. So impressed.
A BEAT as the lie settles. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Remarkable. Kroc smiles back. She’s got him wrapped around her finger JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) I should probably get back.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: To where?  66.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: The piano.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Of course. He nods, privately disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: What’s your favorite song? (BEAT )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All-time favorite. He thinks for a BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: “Pennies From Heaven”. Joan gets up, heads over to the piano. She starts to play Ray immediately recognizes the melody.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Every time it rains, it rains/ Pennies from heaven... ON KROC-- charmed, immensely turned on. JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) Don't you know each cloud contains/ Pennies from heaven? Kroc gets up, heads to the piano. Takes a seat on the ben next to her. Removing her hands from the keys, he starts PLAY THE SONG. And sing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You'll find your fortune fallin’ all over town/ Be sure that your umbrella is upside down... ON JOAN-- surprised and amazed. He leans in, sotto voce: RAY KROC (CONT’D) Worked as an organ salesman for a few years. She smiles, charmed. Possibly genuine. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Trade them for a package of sunshine and flowers... (to Joan) Join in.  67. She does--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC AND JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: If you want the things you love, you must have showers... ON THE ROOM-- eating up the surprise duet. Including Roll RAY KROC AND JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) So when you hear it thunder, don't run under a tree/ There'll be pennies from heaven for you and me BIG APPLAUSE. Kroc stands up and takes a bow, basking in Joan stands up, clapping too.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Bravo, Ray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc gazes out the window in a state of dreamy reverie. I not hard to tell what (or who) he’s thinking about. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - DAY Kroc enters the house. Ethel is in a living-room chair reading a Barbara Cartland romance novel.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: How was the trip?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You want to know?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I’m asking.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It was... triumphant. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rolled out the red carpet for me. I was welcomed like a king. Wherever I went, I was showered with adulation. Admiration. Respect. People were kneeling before me, kissing my ring, practically begging for a McDonald's. A BEAT as Ethel absorbs.  68.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: That’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It was.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: I’m sure. She nods to herself, hard to read. ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) Pope Raymond The First. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc stands before a U.S. MAP on the wall. There are a do or so PUSH PINS stuck in it, mostly clustered around Chic and the upper Midwest. ON KROC-- surveying the map with the bearing of a general hands clasped behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir? June is standing by the door. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) We have a small problem. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc at his desk with June. Spread out before them is the company’s FINANCIAL LEDGER, open to a page.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: How could we be almost out of capital?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Well... She runs her finger down a column of figures.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Your revenue. The monthly cut of the stores.  69.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: 1.4 percent of net.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: 1.9, minus Dick and Mac’s half percent. She seems way more familiar with the terms than he does.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT TIME LATER--
dialogues.text: Kroc is looking at his contract. A passage we glimpsed earlier, at the signing:

dialogues.speaker: AND MAURICE MCDONALD...
dialogues.text: Kroc shakes his head, not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick is accepting a large shipment of cups and plastic wa He signs, hands the clipboard back to the DELIVERY MAN.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. McDonald? Dick turns, sees a YOUNG EMPLOYEE. EMPLOYEE (CONT’D) Ray Kroc on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac stands behind Dick, who picks up the phone, both of t bracing for it.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Hiya, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to renegotiate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renegotiate what? INT. KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Kroc paces, contract in hand. (Intercut as necessary.)

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: My deal. My lousy deal. Dick looks totally taken aback. RAY KROC (CONT’D) 1.4 is barely enough to cover my monthly nut, much less drive expansion.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Ray, those are the terms.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s not enough.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s more than triple our cut.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Then you oughta be getting more, too.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I’m not a greedy man.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s not about greed, it’s about taking care of ourselves so we can take care of this company. If I had more money to work with, we could be growing at twice the pace.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I have no beef with the current rate of expansion.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: We haven't got a single location in New York. Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: All in good time.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Texas! 70.  71.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I have no doubt it’1l come.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I've been busting my hump for you boys.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: And you're doing a bang-up job.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Then I ought to be doing better than just breaking even.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Say you'll renegotiate.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Can't or won’t?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Upping your cut, it wouldn’t be fair to the franchisees.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: The franchisees are doing just fine. I’m the one drowning. Between your molasses approval process and the meager cut...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You freely and willingly agreed to the terms of your deal, Ray. Nobody put a gun to your head.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Four percent.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Three and a half.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GODDAMMIT
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Post-call. Dick is gazing off stormily.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Is he a pain in the rear? Yes. Has he got a few screws loose? Maybe. But that doesn’t mean he’s going to do us any harm.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: How long are you going to keep this up, Mac?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Keep what up?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: The whole “everything is fine” act. (eye contact) There’s a wolf in the henhouse! And we let him in! ON MAC-- looking nauseous. Guilty. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) I never should have listened.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We have a contract, Dick. For just this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I should have trusted my gut.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He’s powerless. BEAT. Dick shakes his head grimly.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Dick.  73. Dick is silent, furious at his brother. At himself.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to have your... He trails off, seemingly losing his train of thought.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just wanted... His face grows flushed. Dick sees something is off.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Mac.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Dickie... ON DICK-- recognizing what this is.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to leave the gate open...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to let Boomer get out...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (moving toward brother) Mac, you're having one of your-- CRASH. Mac flops over, crashing to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SAN BERNARDINO
dialogues.text: Mac is sitting on the floor nursing a milkshake. Next to is a tin box marked GLUCAGON EMERGENCY KIT.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: A few more sips. Mac takes a sip of the shake. His sleeves are rolled up, revealing a MEDIC ALERT BRACELET. Engraved on it is DIABE TYPE 1.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I’m okay. ON DICK-- looking at his brother with love and worry.  74. ON MAC-- gazing off at something... The Multimixer on the counter. Kroc’s machine, used to ma the shake in his hands. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc sits at his desk. Next to a bottle of Canadian Club pile of BILLS AND INVOICES. He picks one up. It’s from ILLINOIS FIRST FEDERAL, stamped PAST DUE. He picks up ano one. From CHICAGO GAS & ELECTRIC. He stares at the amount owed.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Ninety-four dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc in the walk-in cooler with Fred Turner. In Kroc’s ha is the Chicago Gas & Electric bill.

dialogues.speaker: FRED TURNER
dialogues.text: It’s unbelievable what these suckers cost to run. Kroc shakes his head, a knot in his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: FRED TURNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My pop used to own an ice-cream parlor. He went belly-up from the refrigeration costs. Kroc’s eye drifts to the left side of the cooler. The ent side is filled with drums of ice cream (for the milkshake ON KROC-- staring at the drums. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - ENTRANCE/LIVING ROOM - DAY Kroc enters the house. He hangs up his coat and makes a beeline for the liquor cabinet, pours himself a stiff dri

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A man called today. Kroc turns, startled to see Ethel in a recliner in a corn of the darkened room.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Ethel.  75.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: From a bank.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Alright...

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Illinois First Federal.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What did they want?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: You don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Why would I? She gives him an unnerving stare. RAY KROC (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Ray... (eye contact) Did you mortgage our home? ON KROC-- a deer in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc marches through the bank to Harvey Peltz’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I specifically said the office is the best place to reach me! ON PELTZ-- taken aback by the intrusion.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: I tried you there, Mr. Kroc. Numerous times.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You have no right to call me at my home. It is a blatant invasion of privacy.  76.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, when you're three months behind on your payments, you don’t get to pick and choose where you’re contacted. INT. KROC’S CAR - DAY Kroc driving along a highway. A sign appears ahead:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc approaches a gleaming new McDonald’s in downtown Minneapolis. He looks through a window, into the store. ON KROC-- gazing. KROC’S POV: Joan Smith in a McDonald’s apron, looking jus adorable. Pretty much his fantasy image of a woman. Out the corner of her eye, she sees Kroc through the glas She heads out to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (jokey) . Surprise inspection!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Just thought I’d fly up, see how things are going. She smiles, impressed. It makes him feel great. INT. ROLLIE’S STEAKHOUSE - LATER Kroc having dinner with Rollie and Joan.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: That’s some haul for month one.  77.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: And once we clear start-up costs...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You'll be looking at a tidy little profit. Rollie and Joan nod, buzzing over the prospect.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Speaking of which: I hate to mix business with pleasure...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (wry) I don’t. Everyone chuckles. Rollie proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: My expenses...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What about ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Well, they’re a bit higher than anticipated. One in particular... That dang walk-in. ON KROC-- interested to hear more. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) The bill’s a real whopper.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: All that ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s a real problem. A BUSBOY comes by, clears their finished plates.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Now, I don’t want to overstep my bounds here, but I think I may have found a solution. (looks at Joan, proud) Joan did, actually.  78.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You don’t say. Kroc turns to Joan, all ears.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: (salesman-like) What if I told you there was a way to save you, us, and all your owner- operators literally hundreds of dollars a year in electrical costs? Kroc cocks an intrigued eyebrow. JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) And free up valuable storage space. And reduce the amount of time it takes to make a milkshake by half.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I'll bite. She reaches under the table, pulls out her purse. She tak out a copy of RESTAURANT BUSINESS MONTHLY, slides it to K

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Page 22. Kroc opens the trade publication to page 22. A FULL-PAGE for something called INST-A-MIX. The ad copy trumpets:

dialogues.speaker: MIRACULOUS INSTANT ICE-CREAM SUBSTITUTE THAT WILL SAVE YO
dialogues.text: ‘SCOOPFULS’ OF TIME AND MONEY!

dialogues.speaker: OF THE PAST
dialogues.text: JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) A powdered milkshake. Costs a fraction of ice cream, no refrigeration necessary.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Thickening agents and emulsifiers simulate the texture of milk fat. Tastes just like the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN KROC
dialogues.text: And it’s easy as pie to prepare. Just pour the convenient single- serving packet into water and stir.  79. ON KROC-- staring at the ad poker-faced. Rollie and Joan can’t get a read on his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: I realize it may seem a tad blasphemous, what with your dairy- sector background and all.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: But personally... Joan looks at Kroc, touches his hand. JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) I think it’s a marvelous idea. ON KROC-- privately quivering at the touch.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Could I interest anyone in dessert? The WAITER holds out a dessert menu to the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: No thanks, Vic. (to Kroc, cryptic smile) We brought our own.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER--
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON a pair of SILVER-FOIL PACKETS in front of Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Chocolate or vanilla?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Vanilla. Joan takes one of the packets, marked “V”, dumps the powd contents into a glass. She pours in some water, stirs. ON KROC-- watching with fascination as it thickens. Withi seconds, it transforms into what looks like a vanilla sha Joan slides it to Kroc. All eyes on him as he takes a sip long, anxious BEAT from the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I think... I’m drinking a delicious vanilla shake!  80. The table erupts in happy, relieved laughter.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: May I? Kroc follows her eyes to the shake. He gives her a “be my guest” nod. She raises the glass to her lips, takes a lon languorous sip. Kroc watches, highly turned on. She puts the glass down, smiles at Kroc. JOAN SMITH (CONT’D) I couldn’t resist. Kroc’s gaze drifts to the glass. On the rim is a bright-r LIPSTICK MARK. He stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So whaddaya say? Kroc looks at Rollie, shaken out of his moment. ROLLIE SMITH (CONT’D) We try it out at our place. Then, if it goes well...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: You roll it out nationally. ON KROC-- suddenly a tad queasy, thinking of the brothers nods vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I could. A strange, shaky BEAT. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Let me think about it. Rollie and Joan nod, surprised. They were expecting a big unreserved yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Of course. You’re the boss. Kroc nods, privately churning. If they only knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc is sitting on the bed looking at the Inst-A-Mix ad i “Restaurant Business Monthly”. On the nightstand is a pin Four Roses bourbon, empty. He dials the phone.  81.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Just hear me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is closed. Dick is on the front-counter ph

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (instantly wary) Hello, Ray. ON MAC-- cleaning up in the background. His ears prick up

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What if I told you there was a way to save you, me, and all our owner- operators literally hundreds of dollars a year in electrical costs?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: And what would that be?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Two words: Powdered milkshake. (before Dick can reply--) There’s a remarkable new product I recently came across called Inst-A- Mix. It’s a powdered milkshake, costs a fraction of ice cream, no refrigeration necessary.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Ray--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I tried it, and let me tell you, it is delicious. Tastes just like the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Is this some sort of joke?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Comes in vanilla or chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Me, I’m a vanilla man.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I have no interest in a milkshake that contains no milk.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You won’t be able to tell the difference. Guarantee.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Why don’t we put sawdust in the hamburgers while we’re at it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m being serious.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Frozen french fries!

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You don’t want to save a bundle?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Not like that.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: We're talking the same great taste while boosting your bottom line.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It’s called a milk shake, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Not to mention freeing up all that cooler space. I don’t know about you, but I'd sure like to--

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Milk. Now and forever. ON KROC-- shut down. Yet again.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for giving it your full and sincere consideration. (fed up) As always. MOTEL ROOM —- SHORT TIME LATER Kroc silently gazes off. He FLINGS THE MAGAZINE across th room, knocking over a lamp.  83. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc stares at the ever-growing mountain of bills on his desk. His gaze drifts to a letter from ILLINOIS FIRST FED marked FINAL NOTICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc is sitting with Harvey Peltz, his home-mortgage offi

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You've got to extend my line.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: Until you build more equity in your home or pay down the loan...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: My business is booming.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, that’s immaterial.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Thirteen locations in nine states!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: It’s a home-equity loan.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Then give me a business loan. REVEAL, on the other side of a partition: a patrician, si haired BUSINESSMAN sitting across from an empty chair, listening in as he waits for his banker to return.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: These 13 locations. They’re yours?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: You own them?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I mean, not in the strict sense.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: So then what are your assets?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Mine personally?  84.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: It is your business, correct? You own it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Not technically, per se. The businessman cringes for the poor, floundering schlub the other side of the partition. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I’m the head of franchising. I’m the one behind all the growth.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: That’s all well and good, but--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to a McDonald's? The name catches the businessman’s ear. RAY KROC (CONT’D) We've got three stores right here in the Chicagoland area. Perhaps if you swung by, took a look.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: That's quite alright.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I'd be happy to give you a tour, give you a better sense of--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY PELTZ
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’ve got the gist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc exits the bank in defeat. He slumps off toward his c

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Kroc. Kroc turns, sees the man approaching. Kroc looks him over Dressed in an impeccably tailored suit, he has the finish cosmopolitan air of a New Yorker.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: No. But perhaps I can help you.  85. He hands Kroc a business card. Kroc looks at it:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Thanks. We're perfectly happy with our current supplier. Kroc hands back the card, starts to walk off.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: I’m not looking to sell you ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Then what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: I caught a bit of your conversation back there. Sounds like you're having some financial troubles.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Why don’t you mind your own business?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: I’m a great admirer of your establishment.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: That’s very nice.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: I lunch at your Waukegan location at least thrice a week. And not once have I ever failed to witness a large, avid crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Your point being...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: If you’re not making money hand over fist, something is gravely amiss. This gets Kroc’s attention.
Kroc enters the office with Sonneborn. As they pass the f desk:

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: June, fetch the ledger. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc and Sonneborn sit in front of the ledger.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: So to summarize, you have a miniscule revenue stream, no cash reserves, and an albatross of a contract that requires you to go through a glacially slow approval process to enact changes--if they’re approved at all. Which they never are. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I missing anything?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I believe that covers it. ON SONNEBORN-- thinking.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: Tell me about the land.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Land?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: The land, the buildings, how that whole aspect of it works.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Well, it’s pretty simple really. The franchisee finds a piece of land he likes, takes out a lease. Usually 20-year. He gets himself a construction loan, puts up the building, and off he goes.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: So the operator selects the site.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks the property. Not you. Kroc nods, unsure why he’s so curious about all of this. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) You supply the training, the system, the operational know-how, and he’s responsible for the rest.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Correct. ON SONNEBORN-- processing. He seems troubled. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: A big one.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: That you don’t seem to realize what business you’re in. (BEAT )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not in the burger business. You’re in the real-estate business. Kroc looks totally confused. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) You don’t build an empire off a 1.4 percent cut of a 15-cent hamburger. You build it by owning the land upon which that burger is cooked. ON KROC-- wrestling with this strange notion. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) What you ought to be doing is buying up plots of land, then turning around and leasing said plots to franchisees, who as a condition of their deal should be permitted to lease from you and you alone. This will provide you with two things: One, a steady, upfront revenue stream. Money flows in before the first stake is in the ground. Two, greater capital for expansion. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) Which in turn fuels further land acquisition, which in turn fuels further expansion. And so on and so on. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land... That’s where the money is. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And control. Control over the franchisee: Fail to uphold quality standards, you cancel their lease. Control over Dick and Mac: Their power stops at the building’s foundation. Yours goes to the soil. ON KROC-- absorbing, registering the full significance.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: If I were to do this... the brothers... this would effectively...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: Yes. A long BEAT. Kroc searching his soul. We can almost see t Angel and the Devil on his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) So whaddaya say, Ray? The Harry & Ray Show. Sonneborn and Kroc jumping into act --Sonneborn taking meetings with BANKERS AND INVESTORS in York City. Confidently presenting his sweeping vision to conference rooms of heavy hitters. He stands in sharp contrast to Kroc... Kroc is Main Street, Sonneborn is Wal Street. Kroc is a salesman, Sonneborn is a businessman. --Hands being shaken, deals being struck. --Kroc criss-crossing the country by plane shopping for l Scouting suburban neighborhoods, plots of land near schoo and churches. Fertile ground for the planting of arches. --Kroc’s U.S. map filling in with push pins. 15, 20, 30.. --Kroc and Sonneborn presiding over lease signings. MOLIN NASHVILLE, ORLANDO, KALAMAZOO. --New franchisees combing through thick, 100-page agreeme Glimpses of legalese:  89. ...ANY AND ALL CHANGES OR MODIFICATIONS MUST BE...

dialogues.speaker: QUALITY AS DEEMED BY LESSOR, LESSOR HAS THE RIGHT TO...
dialogues.text: Control. For Kroc. END OF MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant, not yet open for the day. A MAILMAN goes to Dick with a stack of mail. Dick opens a LETTER, troubl by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac is wiping down the front counter.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you heard of the Franchise Realty Corporation? Mac turns, sees Dick holding the letter.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I have no clue. But apparently Ray Kroc is president and CEO. Mac takes the letter, instantly nauseous. ANGLE ON letter, written on FRANCHISE REALTY CORPORATION letterhead. The letter itself is some innocuous bit of McDonald's business from Kroc to the brothers. It’s reall just an excuse to flash the letterhead. And the signature the bottom: RAYMOND A. KROC - PRESIDENT/CEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June is at the front desk. She picks up a ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO
dialogues.text: Franchise Realty Corporation, how may I direct your call? Behind her, WORKMEN are taking down the Prince Castle Sal sign and putting up a new one in its place: FRANCHISE REA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. KROC’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Kroc picks up his phone. (Intercut as necessary.)

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hello, Dick. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Well, if you really want to know, I’m tad miffed.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What seems to be the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Franchise Realty Corporation.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: For starters, would you mind telling me what it is?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing really. Just a little something I created to help provide leasing services and support to our new franchisees. Dick can practically hear Kroc’s smirk through the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You know full well you can’t do something like that without first clearing it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Why would I need to do that?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Why? Because as your deal plainly states, any and all changes must—

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s not a change.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s not a change. It’s a company. Its own separate company. Which puts it outside of your purview.  91.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Anything relating to McDonald's is within our--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You boys have full say over what goes on inside the restaurants. But outside? Above? Below?... Your authority stops at the door. And the floor. ON MAC-- standing in the doorway, sick to his stomach. He can’t hear what Kroc is saying, but he knows it’s not goo INT. KROC’S OFFICE - ANOTHER DAY Kroc is leaning against his desk, arms folded confidently big grin on his face. It’s a slightly weird sight until w hear the click of a camera and realize it’s a PHOTO SHOOT

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Let’s try a few by the map. The PHOTOGRAPHER leads Kroc to the expansion map, which i significantly more crowded with pins now. Kroc strikes th same pose, arms winningly crossed. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Good, good. Kroc impulsively grabs a prop hamburger off the desk, hol it up for the camera. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Love it. Kroc playfully pretends to take a big bite. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) (snapping away) That’s a riot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rollie is hustling about the kitchen, supervising the lun rush.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (gruff) Delivery.  92. He turns, expecting to see a delivery man. Instead, Ray K is standing there, leaning against THREE BOXES on a dolly

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (like a delivery guy) Where ya want these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc looks on as Rollie opens one of the boxes, unsure wh inside. ANGLE ON box’s contents: hundreds of silver-foil packets.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: (excited, surprised) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’ve thought it over. ON JOAN-- also there, anxiously awaiting Kroc’s next word RAY KROC (CONT’D) Approved.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Really? Oh, thank you!

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Thank you. It’s a whiz-bang idea. And you thought of it. Kroc revels in the feeling of playing kingmaker.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Well, we’re deeply honored to serve as your test market.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: To heck with that. I’m rolling it out nationally. Joan gasps, honored, thrilled. Her idea, implemented acro the country. ON ROLLIE-- looking at Joan looking at Ray. We finally de the first stirrings of jealousy. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Speaking of Inst-A-Mix, have you seen the new issue of “RBM”?  93. Kroc reaches inside his coat, pulls out a copy of “Restau Business Monthly”. Hands it to Rollie. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Hot off the press. ON ROLLIE-- taking in the cover... ANGLE ON magazine. Kroc is the cover boy. A big photo of in his office, smiling, holding the hamburger. The headli MCDONALD’S TAKES A BITE OUT OF THE COMPETITION - UPSTART HAMBURGER EMPORIUM IS ‘ON THE GROW’ ON JOAN-- looking at Ray on the cover. Looking at Ray in flesh. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Ethel is asleep in bed, alone.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Kroc is on the phone, speaking quietly.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (intrigued) Bloomington... INT. ROLLIE AND JOAN SMITH’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Joan is on the kitchen phone, also speaking softly. She’s wearing a nightie.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: It’s about 10 miles south of downtown. They’re building a brand- new sports stadium there.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I read about that.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: We're getting a professional baseball and football team. They’11l both be playing there.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I think I see where you’re going with this...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: A 40,000-seat stadium, just a stone’s throw away. Imagine the foot traffic.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hungry families looking for a bite after the ballgame.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Or before. Whenever.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I like the way you think, Joan. You think big.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Is there any other way to?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised. His gaze drifts downward. To his wedding ring. RAY KROC (CONT’D) A lot of people, they’re scared. Of taking a chance. Reaching for greatness.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: That’s so sad.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I agree. Ambition, that’s the stuff of life.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: What’s that saying? “Fortune favors the bold.”

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: Just look at you.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Are you calling me bold, Joan?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN SMITH
dialogues.text: You don’t build a restaurant empire acting like a timid little mouse.  95.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Kroc lies in bed next to Ethel. His hands drift downward under the covers, toward his nether regions. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc, Harry Sonneborn and Fred Turner stand huddled over map of Texas.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: (re: some city on map) That's a fast-growing area. The phone rings outside the room. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) And cheaper. You’re talking a good 15 percent less per acre.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I still say Houston’s the move.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir? June Martino is standing in the doorway. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) Dick on line one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick on the phone in his office, Mac in the background.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I just got a very disconcerting call. Kroc on the other end--Harry, Fred and June listening in. Kroc has a smug, cocky air, “playing to the crowd” a bit.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: From Buddy Jepsen. Our operator in Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m well aware who Buddy Jepsen is.  96.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: He told me he received a shipment this morning.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It arrived?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You are way out of line, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I figured it wouldn’t get there until Friday the earliest.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Would you mind telling me what you're doing shipping four cases of Inst-A-Mix to one of our operators?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: If you’re not interested in turning a profit, that’s fine. But please don’t stop the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Us?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Us. As in everyone but you.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Who did you send them to?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Everyone but you.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You have no right, Ray. You are to stop this instant. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You heard me. Nah.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What the hell’s that mean?  97.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It means from now on I’1l be doing things my way.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You will abide by the terms of your deal.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I’m through taking marching orders from you. Bowing to your dictates. You and your endless parade of nos.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You have a contract.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Don’t grow, don’t change... Cower in the face of progress...

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: If phony powdered milkshakes is your idea of progress, you have a profound misunderstanding of what McDonald’s is about.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I have a far better understanding of McDonald’s than you two yokels.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You heard me.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You will do as we say.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You have a contract.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Contracts are like hearts. They’re made to be broken. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - DINING ROOM - NIGHT Kroc and Ethel eat dinner together in edgy silence. All w hear is the sound of knife scraping plate as meat is cut.  98.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL KROC
dialogues.text: Please pass the salt. (he passes it) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Another stretch of silence. Cutting and chewing. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I want a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big, oak-paneled office of a top Chicago law firm. Kr sits across from a LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: It’s not so simple. He looks down at a document in his hand, Kroc’s contract the brothers.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This contract, it’s ironclad.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I don’t care what it takes.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ANOTHER LAWYER’S OFFICE - DAY Virtually the identical scene, except a different office different LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Just get me out.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: She’s gonna put up one hell of a fight.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: She can have it all. The house, the car, the insurance policy...

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: (treading lightly) What about the...  99.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Never. I'd sooner die than give that woman one share of McDonald’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick enters the office. He notices a package on his desk, addressed to him and Mac. He opens it, pulls out a silver foil Inst-A-Mix packet. It’s stamped “8S”. Dick reaches in, pulls out a handwritten note from Kroc: NEW FLAVOR... STRAWBERRY. MAYBE YOU’LL LIKE THIS ONE!

dialogues.speaker: --BEST, RAY
dialogues.text: His dismay is soon eclipsed by something else: The note from Kroc; it’s not on Franchise Realty Corporat letterhead. The letterhead says THE MCDONALD'S CORPORATIO It’s signed at the bottom RAYMOND A. KROC - PRESIDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workmen are taking down the Franchise Realty Corporation at the front desk, a new one going up in its place: THE MCDONALD’S CORPORATION.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was confusing. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Kroc on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: No one knew it had anything to do with McDonald's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick on the other end. Mac there, too.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What’s confusing is you calling yourself the McDonald's Corporation. ON MAC-- listening, strangely calm.  100. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) People will think it’s the whole company, not just the real-estate arm. Which I strongly suspect is what you hope. Without warning, Mac SNATCHES THE PHONE out of Dick’s han

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: IT’S NOT YOUR COMPANY, RAY!

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Mac.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Don’t get all bent out of shape.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We came up with the Speedee System, not you. Us. What did you ever come up with, Ray? Name one thing. You can’t. Because you never have and you never will. You’re a leech! You're a professional leech! ON DICK-- stunned by his brother’s outburst.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Would you like to know what I came up with? I’1l tell you, Mac. I came up with a concept. A highly novel concept called winning. You boys are content to sit back and be a couple of also-rans. To let the future run roughshod over you. Me, I want to take the future. I want to win. And you don’t get there by being some aw-shucks, nice-guy sap. There’s no place in business for people like that. Business is war. It’s rat eat rat, dog eat dog. If my competitor was drowning, I'd reach out and stick a goddamn hose in his mouth. Can you say the same?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I can’t, nor would I want to.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hence your single location.  101.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I want you out of this company.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: And how do you propose to do that?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Whatever it takes. We’ll sue you if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You couldn't afford to sue me. I could bury you in court costs alone. I’m the president and CEO of a major corporation with landholdings in 17 states. You run a burger stand in the desert. (blistering, nuclear) I’m national. You’re fucking local. Kroc hears a loud THUD through the phone. Mac has COLLAPSED to the floor. The wail of an AMBULANCE SIREN carries us to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac lies in a hospital bed looking pale and weak. Dick st by as DR. REEVES talks to Mac.

dialogues.speaker: DR. REEVES
dialogues.text: You've been following your eating plan? (Mac nods) Checking your glucose levels? (Mac nods) Taking your medication on a consistent basis? (Mac nods) Regular walks, 20 minutes a day? (Mac nods) No smoking? (Mac nods) Any stress?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: (BEAT, understatement of century) Some.  102.

dialogues.speaker: DR. REEVES
dialogues.text: You need to watch that. It’s a big contributing factor. The doctor flips to a page in Mac’s chart.

dialogues.speaker: DR. REEVES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I said, your kidney function's currently at 50 percent. 18 months ago, it was 65. Any lower, you’re at serious risk for kidney failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac is doing a crossword puzzle, Dick in a chair nearby. Mac Mac

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: “William Who Rode With Paul Revere.”

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: How many letters?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Five, fourth letter E.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Dawes. pencils it in. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Come in. and Dick look toward the door, stunned to see... Ray Kroc, holding a bouquet of flowers. The

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: How ya feelin’? brothers glare at their unexpected, unwelcome guest. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That was some spill. Felt it all the way through the phone. Kroc extends the flowers to Mac. RAY KROC (CONT’D) For you.  103. Mac takes the flowers like they’re potentially laced with anthrax. He glances at the card attached. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Open it.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: That’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Please. I think you’1l like it. Mac reaches in the envelope, pulls out a GET-WELL CARD. H opens the card. A CHECK falls out. Blank.

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What’s it look like?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: It looks like a blank check.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Then that’s probably what it is. Mac and Dick look at each other. RAY KROC (CONT’D) How much should I make it out for?

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: What are you buying? Kroc flashes them a “You don’t know?” smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac and Dick both gazing off gloomily. After a long stret of silence--

dialogues.speaker: MAC MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We'll never beat him. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never be rid of him. ON DICK-- absorbing. He knows Mac is right.  104. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc is standing before the franchise map. There are near 50 PINS in it now. The intercom buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE MARTINO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dick McDonald. Kroc picks up, friendly and casual.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hiya, Dick. On the other end is Dick, in the KITCHEN in San Bernardin

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: $2.7 million. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million for each of us after taxes. ON KROC-- taken aback by the staggering sum. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) And one percent of the company’s profits in perpetuity. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc is pacing furiously before Harry Sonneborn.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s outrageous! Borderline extortion! Sonneborn is holding a document. A PURCHASE PROPOSAL from brothers.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: And they want one other thing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: San Bernardino. Kroc is taken aback. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) To give to their longtime employees. As a gift.  105.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: I need San Bernardino. I was counting on its profits to cover the debt on the purchase loan.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY SONNEBORN
dialogues.text: I've spoken at length about it with their lawyers. It’s unfortunately non-negotiable. ON KROC-- calmly absorbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc and the brothers in a conference room, flanked by th respective teams of LAWYERS.

dialogues.speaker: KROC LAWYER
dialogues.text: Our client agrees fully to your conditions of sale. With one exception. Your one percent cut of future corporate earnings will have to be carried out on a handshake basis.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: On the insistence of my investor group. Their financing is contingent on leaving it out of the contract. It’s unfortunately a dealbreaker for them. Dick and Mac look at each other, extremely wary. RAY KROC (CONT’D) You have my word you’1ll get your full due royalties. He extends his hand, holding it out to them.

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Mac and Dick sit alone in the conference room as their lawyers pack up. (Kroc and his team are gone.) ON MAC-- staring somberly at a check in his hands for $1,350,000. ON DICK-- staring somberly at a check in his hands for $1,350,000.  106. INT. MEN'S ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Kroc is at the urinal in the law office’s men’s room. He flushes, heads to the sink to wash his hands. The rest room door opens. In walks Dick. He freezes at th sight of Kroc. Kroc smiles amiably at him in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Hello, Dick. ON DICK-- gazing searchingly at Kroc.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: I just have to ask you one thing. Something I’ve never understood.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: That day we met, when we gave you the tour.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: We showed you everything. The whole system, all our secrets. We were an open book. (Kroc nods) So why didn’t you just--

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Rip you off? Run off and start my own place using your ideas? (Dick nods) Because it would have failed.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who ever got the kitchen tour? I bet you invited loads of people back there. Countless would-be burger barons looking to replicate your success.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: How many succeeded?

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Lots of people started restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Bigger than McDonald's? (Dick is silent) Of course not. No one has and no one ever will. Because they all lack that one thing that makes McDonald's special.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Which is...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Even you don’t know!

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: Enlighten me.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: It’s not just the system. It’s the name. Dick doesn’t follow. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That name. That glorious name. McDonald. It’s wide open. Limitless. It could be anything, whatever you want it to be. It sounds like... America. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compare that to, oh, say, Kroc. Now there’s a real lemon. Kroc. What a erock. Load of crock. Crock of shit. Would you eat at a place called Kroc’s? It’s enough to make you lose your appetite, a blunt, Slavic thing like that. But McDonald's, now that’s a name. A fine, handsome, all-American name. That’s a winner’s name, the name of somebody who’s got the world by the tail. A man named McDonald is never going to get pushed around in life.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: That’s clearly not the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don’t have a check for $1.35 million in your pocket? Dick is silenced. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That's the mistake your competitors made. All those would-be imitators. They assumed they could simply take your system, slap on some name like Hamburger Hamlet or Roscoe’s, and presto! Instant success! Not me, I wasn’t so arrogant. I knew there’s no beating a name like McDonald's.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: And if you can’t beat ‘em...

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Buy ‘em. Dick chuckles in disgust. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I'll never forget the first time I saw that name stretched across the front of your stand. It was love at first sight. From that moment, I knew I just had to have it. And now I do.

dialogues.speaker: DICK MCDONALD
dialogues.text: You don’t “have” it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: You sure about that? Kroc throws him an unnerving smile.
ANGLE ON the McDonald’s sign in front of the restaurant. PAN DOWN TO... Dick and Mac with Kroc’s lawyers, listenin like they’re being read their Miranda rights.  109.

dialogues.speaker: KROC LAWYER
dialogues.text: As per the terms of your agreement, while you are entitled to maintain ownership of this location, you no longer have the right to call it McDonald’s, McDonald or any other such variation so as to create confusion or infringe upon the McDonald’s trademark which is now the exclusive intellectual property of Mr. Raymond A. Kroc.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Workers dismantling the McDonald’s sign. The brothers wat helplessly as their name is removed from their own store.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: A new sign going up in its place. With a new name--

dialogues.speaker: THE BIG M
dialogues.text: Below this, it says, with a whiff of desperation: “WE HAVE BEEN HERE 23 YEARS!” The sign is as close to a McDonald's marquee as is legall possible, but it’s just not McDonald's. It’s heartbreakin PAN ACROSS THE STREET, where we see... A NEW MCDONALD'S under construction. A hard-hatted Kroc i site, watching as the signature Golden Arches go up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Kroc? A YOUNG MAN comes over, slightly nervous to approach. YOUNG MAN (CONT’D) My name is Will Davis. I'ma reporter for the Los Angeles Times. I’m interested in doing a profile of you pegged to the opening of your hundredth location here. A BEAT as Kroc thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Call my office. They’1l set it up. He reaches into the breast pocket of his sport coat.  110. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Here’s my card. He hands a BUSINESS CARD to the reporter. He looks at it. ANGLE ON card. Beneath a McDonald’s logo, it says, simply

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: We hold on this for a long BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Now, I know what you’re thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavish, gated MANSION. A BLACK LIMOUSINE pulls into the driveway. INT. MANSION - MASTER BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS A tuxedo-clad Ray Kroc stands before a mirror, stack of i cards in hand. He’s 68 now; it’s nine years later, 1970.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: How the heck does an over-the-hill 52-year-old milkshake-machine salesman build a fast-food empire with 1,600 restaurants in 50 states and five foreign countries, with annual revenues in the neighborhood of $700 million? It’s quite simple: persistence. He turns to the next card. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Nothing in the world can take the place of good old persistence. Talent won't. Nothing’s more common than unsuccessful men with talent. Genius won't. Unrecognized genius is practically a cliché. His words have a familiar ring... They’re lifted straight from “The Power Of The Positive” by Dr. Clarence Floyd Ne (the record from the beginning of the movie), with just a of rephrasing to make it “his own”. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Education won’t. The world is full of educated fools. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAY KROC (CONT’D) Persistence and determination alone are all-powerful. He pauses a beat to let his words of wisdom sink in. RAY KROC (CONT’D) There’s no obstacle under the sun that can’t be overcome with honest hard work and determination. It’s these core principles that enabled me to rise to the top of the heap at a point in life when most men would be thinking about retirement. (glances to side, sly grin) We appear to have that in common, Mr. Governor. He pauses for laughter. RAY KROC (CONT’D) You were, what, 55 when you started in politics? Why, you make me look like a spring chicken! Another pause for laughter. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Look at us, a couple of small-town Illinois boys made good. Only in America... He continues talking to Mr. Governor off to the side-- RAY KROC (CONT’D) By the way, thank you for that splendid introduction. To be named California Chamber of Commerce Man of The Year is thrill enough, but to be presented the award by my dear friend and golf buddy Ronald Reagan, well, that’s just the cherry on the sundae. He turns to the next index card. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Now where was I? Ah, yes, the beginning. The year was 1954. The place, Des Plaines, Illinois. That's where it all started. Right there on Lee Street--  112.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN KROC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The car’s out front. Joan Smith, now Joan Kroc, comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: (to her reflection) Be right down. She nods, exits the room. Kroc looks down at the card in his hand, finding his plac

dialogues.speaker: IT ALL STARTED. RIGHT THERE ON LEE STREET... MCDONALD'S
dialogues.text: RAY KROC (CONT’D) --McDonald's #1. Kroc’s eyes linger on those words on the card: MCDONALD’S He looks up, stares at himself in the mirror for a long B As he takes in his reflection, we detect a flicker of something on his face. Regret? Guilt?... It may have just been our imagination. He tucks the index cards in his pocket, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kroc and Joan Smith (now JOAN KROC) ride in the back of a stretch limo. She’s in a powder-blue gown, draped in diam and pearls.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO DRIVER
dialogues.text: Comfortable, Mr. Kroc? An air conditioning vent blows cool air on Kroc.

dialogues.speaker: RAY KROC
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. (placid) Very. CAMERA slowly pushes in on Kroc’s face as he rides in silence. He looks at Joan, smiles. He indeed seems comfortable. Very. FADE TO BLACK.  113.

dialogues.speaker: POSTSCRIPT
dialogues.text: Ray Kroc’s San Bernardino McDonald’s was an instant hit, drawing customers away from The Big M across the street, forcing it to close. The McDonald brothers were driven ou business by a McDonald’s. Kroc later reneged on the handshake deal for the one perc cut of royalties. The brothers never received a cent. Tod that one percent would be worth $200 million annually. Ea From the moment Kroc took ownership, his business card li his title as “Founder”. Until his death decades later, ca to McDonald’s headquarters asking the origin of the name told it was made up. Kroc married Joan Smith in 1969. They remained together u his death in 1984. In 1971, Mac died of diabetes-related illness. His brothe Dick passed away in 1998. Harry Sonneborn and Ray Kroc had a falling out in 1967. Sonneborn sold all his shares in McDonald’s and never spo to Kroc again. Thanks to Sonneborn’s idea, McDonald’s is today the large owner of real estate in the world.
